author: oklokl
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

https://github.com/DigitalRuby/IPBan/releases
First of all, we have a website.
Here I want to download a file.

`IPBan-Windows-x64_1_8_0.zip`
`powershell.exe -Command "& {Invoke-WebRequest -OutFile $env:ProgramFiles\IPBan\IPBan-Windows-x64_1_8_0.zip -Uri "https://github.com/DigitalRuby/IPBan/releases/download/1.8.0/IPBan-Windows-x64_1_8_0.zip"}`
I can download like this.
But what I want.

I'd like to configure a command that automatically receives the file with the highest number all the time.

`powershell.exe -Command "& {Invoke-WebRequest -OutFile $env:ProgramFiles\IPBan\IPBan-Windows-x64???.zip -Uri "https://github.com/DigitalRuby/IPBan/releases/download/*/IPBan-Windows-x64*.zip" -New -One}`

`-One` Get one file command. my imagination.

`-New -One` I came up with the idea.
if i do this Retrieves and receives the highest number of files in the path. no see.
I'm a computer novice, so my comprehension is poor.
sorry. Please understand.

`releases/download/1.8.0(random)/IPBan-Windows-x64_1_8_0(random).zip`

In this case, what should I do.. Search through the command
Can I download it?...

If I know it, I think it can be applied to various areas.
I don't speak English, so I used Google Translate.

thank you.

Organize my writing.
My goal is to get the latest version files that are currently released.
through the command. That's my goal.
:)

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

idea
random address. It is marked with `???`.
`Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://test.com/dd/???/test*.zip`

`Invoke-WebRequest -Uri -New` = Lets you select the highest number.
`Invoke-WebRequest -Uri -New1~6`, from the highest file to 6 output.

`-Old` the same. Measure from the bottom of the number. Alphabet is the same.
`-Old 1~6` numbers can be set by yourself.

Include all url addresses like test*.zip dir command.
application `*test*.zip`

`https://test.com/dd/[1-5,A-F]/test*.zip`
Only numbers from 1 to 5 are accepted. And if there is an alphabet after it, A to F are allowed.

for example
`Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://test.com/dd/1A2B3d3/test*.zip`
This address is verified as the correct address. let me bring

Applications
`Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://test.com/dd/[1~5,A-F.1~5,A-F.1~5,A-F]/test*.zip`
The address is expressed by putting a dot in the middle.

`Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://test.com/dd/1A2B3d3.1A2B3d3.1A2B3d3/test*.zip`

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
The idea is nice. However there is no standard URL you can send to ask for the URL of the latest version. A lot of the time what has to happen is  GET  /SomePage ; process the result to find the latest version or URL for another version; then Get /FileYouReallyWant. 

It would be easy enough to write for one target, but it doesn't generalize

comments.author: oklokl
comments.body:
https://kin.naver.com/qna/detail.nhn?d1Id=1&dirId=104&docId=432288858

```
md "%USERPROFILE%\Downloads\IPBan"
cd "%USERPROFILE%\Downloads\IPBan"
$target = (Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'https://github.com/DigitalRuby/IPBan/releases').Links.Href | findstr "tree";$targetStr = "";foreach($Line in $target) {$targetStr = $Line;break;}foreach($Line in $targetStr.Split('/')) {$targetStr1 = $Line;}$targetStr2 = $targetStr1 -replace "\.","_";Invoke-WebRequest ('https://github.com/DigitalRuby/IPBan/releases/download/'+$targetStr1+'/IPBan-Windows-x64_'+ $targetStr2 + '.zip') -OutFile ('%USERPROFILE%\Downloads\IPBan\IPBan-Windows-x64.zip');
```

Good news for me.. you made it available for download. He is a Seoul Korea expert. Naver intellectuals (forum Q/A to ask anything)
I didn't make it.
I mostly use single line commands.
:)

Since I often order from this person, he made them in one line.
I thought it would be impossible.

He seems to have kidnapped aliens. My humor..

thank you.
